Neither, therefore, is it possible to give a breakdown of the specific maintenance works for which each unit is used, or to generate reliable data on equipment use rates and availability. In order to arrive at a satisfactory appraisal of the state of the equipment fleet and ascertain whether the present fleet is large enough, the following would be required: (a) an inventory of all units, including their mechanical condition; (b) a highway and rural road maintenance program; and (c) an estimate -- based on the program -- of the types of units needed, and the number needed of each type. The technical assistance team financed under Loan 3350-DO to advise on maintenance management is currently working on these three aspects of the problem. 1.07 Workshops. At the present time, DGM operates the following workshops: (a) Two Type A workshops in Santo Domingo (i.e. supporting the subdistrict workshops), one for vehicles (light mechanics) and the other for equipment (heavy mechanics); (b) one Type A workshop for equipment in Santiago, with similar capacity to the one in Santo Domingo; (c) six Type B workshops (responsible for preventive maintenance and repair of minor components), located in Azua, San Francisco de Macoris, Montecristi, San Pedro de Macoris, San Juan, and Barahona; and (d) eight Type C workshops (only for preventive maintenance), located in Monte Plata, Mao, Loma de Cabrera, San Crist6bal, Higuey, Cotui, Nagua, and Duverge. 1.08 The functions of each workshop depend on its classification, although the information available on jobs in progress leaves much to be desired. Communication and coordination among the various workshops is less than adequate, although terms of reference governing their
 - 56 - organization and functions were drawn up. Consultants are preparing a new organization and functions for the workshops, reducing their number and potential capacity to coincide with the gradual cutback in maintenance by force account. 1.09 Warehouses. DGM operates a central warehouse in Santo Domingo, set up as the lead unit in charge of organizing and supervising the other warehouses and supplying them with spare parts purchased by itself In the districts and subdistricts, DGM operates fourteen more warehouse facilities, which hold a reduced inventory of spares that are requisitioned as necessary for delivery to the workshops. 1.10 There is not the kind of communication between the central and satellite warehouses which allows the stocks held in each of them to be determined at a given moment. Nor are periodic checks made to ascertain whether inventory recorded as being in stock coincides with actual holdings. Despite the merging of the two former General Directorates in 1987, there are cases of duplication of facilities, making it advisable to carry out a study to determine which should be retained. The consultants are also preparing a new warehousing plan consistent with the staffing and equipment cutbacks referred to above. 1.11 Training. Personnel training began under the Second Road Maintenance and Reconstruction Project (Loan 1784-DO), with the establishment of "training production units" (UPEs) directed by Roy Jorgensen Associates, Inc., consultants. The training methodology consisted of intensive theoretical instruction backed up by practical classes supervised and conducted by previously trained instructors. The practical component involved maintenance of road sections (as part of the mobile UPE) plus repair of equipment (as part of the mechanics UPE). From 1981 to 1986, continuous financing was available for these training arrangements, which included building and launching the Santa Caputa workshop in Sanchez. The results speak for themselves: more than 600 individuals trained, some of them to the level of first class mechanic; rehabilitation of 39 equipment units; and repairs on a total of 105 units. 1.12 Following the merger of the two General Directorates, training center operations were discontinued, and the facility itself was dismantled in February 1990. As far as current problems are concerned, which have to do mainly with equipment management, an operator training program has been launched as part of the ongoing project, with another for mechanics to follow. B. Maintenance Management and Programs 2.01 Background: Resource allocations for road maintenance (routine and periodic) and rehabilitation were adequate until approximately 1958, after which a process of steady deterioration set in, reaching its lowest point in the early 70s. From 1976 to 1980 there was some overall improvement, but between 1980 and 1986 overstaffing, in conjunction with the oil crisis, which greatly reduced the country's reserves, resulted in a significant limit on the resources available for the road sector, to the point that the maintenance battle was virtually lost (Graph 2). 2.02 Inadequate maintenance only accelerated the general degree of road deterioration, until finally the whole network needed rehabilitation,. This was begun under Loan 2609-DO, which
 - 57 - included financing for the reconstruction of some of the most important highway sections. With the backing of this loan -- and later that of Loan 33 50-DO, which was declared effective in December 1992 -- the Dominican Government launched a massive road reconstruction/ rehabilitation offensive in 1987, which meant that there was once again some point to organizing maintenance programs. By mid 1994, the policy of reconstruction or rehabilitation had returned 70% of the road system to a state of good or fair condition -- a figure projected to rise to 87% by the end of 1997. In these circumstances, it makes very good sense to strengthen SEOPC administratively and technically to monitor the execution of preventive maintenance tasks -- something that could not be done during earlier periods of technical assistance (1976-1987), when the road system was markedly deteriorated. Graph 2: Real Maintenance Expenditure / Optimal Maintenance Expenditure 14. 12 10 8-6 mop0 4 M 0 1972 1982 1992 1995 IN Real Expenditure *Optimal Expenditure 2.03 Since its current road maintenance planning and programming capability is limited, the DGM normally relies on the Department of Pavement Management and Studies (DAEP) and the Directorate General of Investment Planning and Programming to draw up its annual budgets and programs, although without the kind of annually updated survey of the road system condition that would allow realistic budgeting for necessary activities. As a result of these shortcomings, the annual budgets prepared for the last three years have been similar in terms of quantities of work and cost estimates -- in other words, hardly more than a hollow formality. As regards the monitoring and evaluation of program execution, the data the districts are supposed to send in to the DGM Planning Unit are either incomplete or nonexistent, which means it is unable to make a comparative analysis of programmed versus actual performance and therefore, to produce any ex post evaluation.
 - 58 - 2.04 The practice until quite recently was for SEOPC itself to execute the maintenance program. Contracting out of periodic maintenance to private sector firm's began to gain ground under Loan 2609-DO, increased significantly under Loan 3350-DO and is currently the norm in the periodic maintenance of paved roads (resealing, resurfacing). Routine maintenance, however, is carried out with SEOPC personnel and equipment, although not satisfactorily or efficiently. Senior SEOPC management has fully accepted the need for a preventive maintenance system which safeguards the investment already made, but it is still necessary to insist on this policy with middle management and to set up the required organization. In a move to rectify present maintenance planning and execution arrangements, the technical assistance consultants financed under Loan 3350-DO are introducing a maintenance management system, recommending procedures for the contracting out of preventive (routine) maintenance, and training the SEOPC personnel who will be planning and monitoring maintenance programs in the future. The proposed project would finance: (i) a pilot program to foster and develop the contracting out of routine maintenance as a first step, and of all maintenance subsequently, and (ii) technical assistance and goods required for completion of the necessary institutional development. 2.05 Future Management and Organization: In addition to contributing substantially to the Government's ongoing road reconstruction/rehabilitation effort, Loan 3350-DO included two important components focused on ensuring that the benefit of that effort would be sustainable: (a) the previously mentioned technical assistance with introduction of a road maintenance management system (SAMC) and preparation for the contracting out of routine maintenance; and (b) a pavement technology transfer program (periodic maintenance). Both programs began in early 1995 and are expected to conclude in 1997, with the following results: (a) institutionalization, within SEOPC, of a management system that will allow programming, monitoring and evaluation of preventive and periodic road maintenance; (b) implementation of contracting maintenance activities out to private sector enterprises, strengthening of the current practice of contracting out present periodic maintenance (sealing and surfacing), and introducing contracting out of routine maintenance (including patching) -- programs for which the proposed project includes financing; (c) technical and managerial upgrading of firms engaged in road maintenance, through the transfer of appropriate technology, especially in selection of materials, use of equipment and tools, operating and construction methods, and organization and management; (d) establishment of a road maintenance fund, which guarantees the availability of funds for programmed maintenance (through special accounts earmarked for the deposit of user charges), and administration of this fund by a new road agency -- possibly a joint organization combining government and user representatives;
 - 59 - (e) development of an ongoing training program for DGM personnel, focused on recognition of the profession of "road maintenance specialist" under the provisions of the Civil Service Act. 2.06 Management System. The road maintenance management system, under implementation in the DGM with funds provided under Loan 3350-DO, follows the general outlines indicated above and is being introduced in the following stages: (a) 1995-2000: Restructuring of the road maintenance organization, with special attention to be paid to: (i) preparation of the road condition inventory, including traffic data; (ii) cataloguing of job positions, introduction of the administrative career of road maintenance specialist and preparation of a program for institutional reorganization of the road maintenance system. These aspects will be kept in time with the gradual implementation of maintenance by contract, which will begin in 1997 and will be extended to the whole network by 2001 (Table A2.2). Charts I and II show, respectively, an initial proposal for DGM's management structure and the corresponding organization chart. 2.09 Resource Control. The financial resources required to ensure an acceptable level of maintenance (routine and periodic) amount to approximately DR$160 million (US$13 million) per year. This sum is large enough to warrant not only management and execution of the related works programs but also the backing of decisions to ensure that those funds are spent rationally and efficiently. In addition, the programming and budgeting for all maintenance work, whether preventive or periodic, is approved by the Executive Branch and endorsed by the Congress via enactment of each year's Budget Law. This means that the Office of the Inspector General ('Contralor") of the Republic has to verify -- at least through financial audits -- that budgetary commitments have been fulfilled. Furthennore, the proposed project calls for introduction of both technical and financial audit by independent technical and financial auditors (see main text, paras. 1.29, 2.06 and 3.07, and Annex 11.) to monitor the impact on maintenance expenditures and activities of the proposed reforms.

 - 69 - ANNEX 4 DOMINICAN REPUBLIC NATIONAL HIGHWAY PROJECT PREVIOUS BANK EXPERIENCE IN THE TRANSPORT SECTOR 1. The Bank's past involvement in the road transport sub-sector dates back to 1973, when it acted as the executing agency for the UNDP-financed Highway Rehabilitation and Administration Study. Between 1976 and 1985, three highway projects were financed under Bank loans, totaling US$65 million, to improve the condition of some 320 kmi, or about six percent of the highway network. Those projects were: the First Road Maintenance and Reconstruction Project; the Emergency Road Reconstruction Project; and, the Second Road Maintenance and Reconstruction Project. 2. The First Road Maintenance and Reconstruction Project (Loan 1316-DO, US$5 million, 1976) provided for the reconstruction of a section of the Duarte highway connecting the capital with Santiago, the second largest city. Other components were a bridge rehabilitation program and support to the Road Maintenance Directorate of SEOPC. The Project Performance Audit Report No. 3716 (Board Doc. No. Sec. M-81- 987) of 1981 indicated that project implementation generally developed as planned, but price increases forced a reduction in the scope of the project since it took 2.5 years to achieve congressional ratification and effectiveness of the loan. 3. The second Bank operation was an Emergency Road Reconstruction Project (Loan 1783-DO, US$25 million, 1980), which was approved by the Bank in the wake of the September 1979 hurricane. It supported reconstruction of 150 km of hurricane- damaged roads connecting agricultural areas in the northwest with Santiago and in the southwest with Santo Domingo. Because of its emergency nature, the loan was approved by the Bank before engineering designs were available for the project. When these were later completed and bids were received, it became evident, even after lowering standards to obtain cost savings, that project costs would be about 50% above those estimated at loan approval. The Project Completion Report (December 1984) indicates that beginning implementation of the project on the basis of incomplete engineering work was the primary cause of later delays and cost increases, but that the project, when completed, remained economically justified. 4. The third road project was the Second Road Maintenance and Reconstruction Project (Loan 1784-DO, US$35 million, 1980), amended in 1983 to provide the necessary financing to complete the Emergency Project's road works. The amendment, resulting in the expenditure of some of the funds originally intended for the Second Road Maintenance and Reconstruction Project, caused, in turn, an unfinanced gap for civil works originally included in that project. To remedy this, one of the main objectives of the Third (fourth project) Road Reconstruction Project was to close the financing gap to complete reconstruction of the 150 km that were not finished under the Loan 1784-DO.
 - 70 - 5. In 1986 the fourth operation, the Third Road Reconstruction Project (Loan 2609- DO, US$35.8 million) was approved. It provided financing for: reconstruction of 150 km of highways that were started under Loan 1784-DO, and about 60 km of other high- priority highways; purchase of road maintenance equipment and spare parts; consulting services for construction supervision; a transport planning study; and assistance in training the Pavement Division staff of DGPP and in organizing workshops and stores. Generally, the project was executed as planned and completed on December 31, 1993. 6. The project's scope was appropriate for the country's needs but its implementation was beset by problems which delayed its completion. Most of the roads, especially those added to the road program in 1990, were finished in good time. However, the completion of some reconstruction works contracted in 1981 took about six to ten years (1981-1991) instead of four, as originally scheduled. In retrospect, the problems with these roads could have been avoided had more attention been given during project preparation to avoid repetition of problems experienced by the SEOPC (which hindered implementation of preceding Bank financed projects) namely, starting project implementation with inadequately prepared engineering and deficient planning and programming for the execution of the road works initially included in the project. On the other hand, engineering designs and procurement procedures prepared for the reconstruction works that were added to the works program in 1990 improved markedly and the works were successfully carried out within their allocated budgets, under the supervision of a competent local consulting firm. 7. The lessons learned confirm that to ensure successful implementation of Bank projects it is necessary, during the project preparation stage, to emphasize the need for uncompromising quality of engineering designs and contracting qualified contractors and consultants. Other issues which should have been addressed concerned the Borrowers' sense of ownership of some project components (in particular the Transport Plan) and its commitment to support and achieve the agreed project objectives for those components by providing the required human and financial resources and logistic support. The project also demonstrated the benefit of maintaining an open and productive dialogue with the Borrower, which apparently resulted in a more intensive involvement of SEOPC's higher level staff in the execution of the project, facilitating the project's implementation and ensuring close collaboration with the pre>ect executing agency. 8. The Fifth Road Rehabilitation and Maintenance Project (Loan 3350-DO, US$79 million, 1991) was declared effective on December 2, 1992. The project comprises: (a) rehabilitation of about 830 km of roads and supervision of these works; (b) a technology transfer program on pavements, including technical assistance and civil works; (c) bridge and workshop rehabilitation; (d) equipment rehabilitation; (e) acquisition of road signaling materials, maintenance equipment and scales for vehicle weight control; and (f) technical assistance for training SEOPC's maintenance staff, road maintenance management, an urban transport study, a local construction industry study and engineering services for road design.
 - 71 - 9. Past lessons learned have helped to successfully implement this project. Prequalification of contractors and bidding documents were agreed at negotiations; ICB procedures applied to all civil works of the road rehabilitation program; engineering designs were prepared well in advance to the bidding process; and the open dialogue with the Borrower continued. As a result, procurement is already completed; the contract for the pavement technology transfer program (a major component) is satisfactorily underway; compliance with loan covenants and the Action Plan is acceptable; and about 75% of the loan is already disbursed. 10. However, the proceeds of the Loan will only reach to finance about 70% of the length of highway rehabilitation originally programmed. The main reasons for this reduction are cost increases for civil works, due to higher unit costs and the additional road deterioration that took place since the project was appraised and, above all, the upgrade of most of the works from rehabilitation to reconstruction. On the other hand, the SEOPC rehabilitated more than 900 km in the same period with local funds, which is more than the length finally not financed by the Loan. The technology transfer program, a single component and the biggest contract of the project (including about 500 Km of highway resurfacing) is being implemented as planned and within the resources allocated in the Loan.

Los servicios que se describen en los parrafos siguientes del presente documento se refieren a la supervisi6n de las obras civiles de ampliaci6n, construcci6n y reconstrucci6n de carreteras y puentes incluidas en el proyecto que se propone. Las firmas consultoras interesadas deberan conocer todos los documentos de licitaci6n de las obras a supervisar, asi como toda aquella informaci6n que fuese necesario recopilar para la evaluaci6n de los requerimientos y la confecci6n de su oferta. 2. Informes y Documentos. Todos los informes y documentos se presentarin en formato 81/2xl 1" y los planos doblados en el mismo formato. Se seguira una secuencia numerada. En la portada constara el titulo del proyecto, nuimero del informe y contenido. Los informes tendran indice y paginas numeradas. 3. Revisi6n Inicial de los Proyectos. Dado el tiempo transcurrido entre la toma de datos, la redacci6n del proyecto base, la licitaci6n y la adjudicaci6n de las obras y el comienzo de las mismas, la primera tarea del Consultor serk, la revisi6n, y modificaci6n en su caso, del "proyecto de ejecuci6n" que debera realizar en el plazo de 2 meses. El supervisor podra utilizar toda aquella informaci6n del proyecto base que considere oportuna y la complementara hasta concluir un documento que identifique y defina claramente la obra a ejecutar y permita al contratista la construcci6n y su programaci6n sin vacios de definici6n. Las posibles modificaciones que se consideren y los variaciones presupuestarias que resulten seran discutidas y aprobadas en su caso por la SEOPC, siempre dentro del alcance inicial del proyecto base. 4. Plan de Control. El plan de control consistira basicamente en la definici6n de una guia de toma de datos, ensayos, medidas y comprobaciones para cada unidad y fase de obra, estableciendo parametros minimos y criterios de aceptaci6n para el avance de la obra, la observaci6n y paralizaci6n de esta, su aprobaci6n o su rechazo; estableciendo para ello un conjunto de sistemas de operaci6n. Este plan sera sometido a la SEOPC para su aprobaci6n. Tambien se establecera una colecci6n de formularios para ensayos de laboratorio y otros controles que permitan su mejor identificaci6n, seguimiento y archivo, definiendo dos campos: control geometrico y control de calidad. El primer campo para verificar: (i) la concordancia de la construcci6n con las lineas generales de proyecto, y las tolerancias asumibles; y (ii) las mediciones, y cubicaciones del contratista. El segundo campo para verificar: (i) el cumplimiento de las especificaciones y normativa, estableciendo al mismo tiempo frecuencia y tolerancias; y (ii) el cumplimiento de los estandares de calidad en el proceso constructivo.

 - 129 - ANNEX 7 DOMINICAN REPUBLIC NATIONAL HIGHWAYS PROJECT ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECrS A. Key Environmental Issues 1. Most physical improvements under the project consist of the rehabilitation or reconstruction of existing facilities and, therefore, direct environmental impacts on natural systems and right-of-ways will be of less importance. However, there is evidence of increasing erosion, slope stability and drainage impacts along existing roads caused by original improper design and construction and the absence of environmentally sound maintenance practices. The project also includes the construction of four short (20.3 km in total) by-passes around mid-sized towns. 2. At present, SEOPC's capability to address environmental issues associated with roads and other transport projects is very weak. The Department for the Control of Earth Excavation (DCCT) in SEOPC was created in 1971 in order to prevent indiscriminate excavation and destruction of the environment in borrow pits and construction material mines. Although the institutional strengthening of DCCT has been included as a component of previous road sector projects financed by the Bank, the DCCT has not yet developed the capabilities and technical experience to address those and other environmental concerns in the sector. At present, the DCCT is understaffed and without a clear role in the day to day functions within the SEOPC. 3. There are then three principal categories of environmental concerns related to this project, which include: (i) the environrental management of road rehabilitation and by-pass construction works proposed under the project; (ii) the need to strengthen SEOPC's institutional capability to manage environmental issues related to road and transport projects; and (iii) the need for adopting an environmental manual or environmental guidelines for road construction, rehabilitation and maintenance. B. Environmental Screening of Project Works 4. An Environmental Assessment study on the works included in the proposed project was carried out by a group of national and international consultants, financed under the ongoing loan 3350-DO. The final EA report was delivered before appraisal. 5. Most of the area of influence of the roads concerned has been intervened for decades. Principal land use activities include agriculture (sugar cane, rice, tobacco, and coffee) and cattle ranching. Only one of the proposed works (one by-pass) will cross a small mangrove forest patch. The principal characteristics of screened rehabilitation and by-passes works as well as some physical baseline information are presented in Attachment 1 to this Annex. 6. The proposed works will have little to moderate environmental impacts. Most environmental concerns are associated with (i) the appropriate management of construction
 - 130 - wastes and construction activities (most road rehabilitation and reconstruction sub-projects); (ii) the crossing of drainage and streams that eventually feed to mangrove and wetlands, and other sensitive areas such as irrigation canals (one rehabilitation sub-project and one by-pass); and (iii) right of way expansion in densely populated areas (one rehabilitation sub-project and one by- pass). All these impacts have been identified and appropriate mitigation measures have been proposed and incorporated in project design. For instance, clearing of mangrove trees for the crossing of the Higuamo River was avoided with an innovative bridge design that would span over the riverine trees. All mitigation measures in turn will be included in all bidding documents and construction contracts as well as supervision activities. A summary matrix of environmental impacts and mitigation measures for each sub-project are presented in Attachments 2 and 3 to this Annex. 7. All proposed works, particularly the proposed new by-passes, were screened for their potential resettlement of population. Different alignments were considered and systematically compared according to their technical, ecological and social merits. One of the proposed alignments for the Bani by-pass, for instance, would have displaced over 200 poor urban families in that city. Alternative routes are not technically available since the population opposes new road construction between the city and the ocean front. In this manner, the selected alternative would upgrade the existing accesses and build a second bridge to replace the existing one at the entrance of the town. All other by-passes will not have any significant need for resettlement. C. Environmental Institutional Strengthening of SEOPC 8. Although the Dominican Republic's environmental regulatory and institutional framework is at present weak, it is clear that the SEOPC has an overall responsibility to address environmental issues for public works and communications. The most expedite mechanism to promote an adequate environmental management of sectorial projects would be to expand the functions and staff within the DCCT into an Environmental Unit to manage environmental aspects of road and transport projects in addition to the existing functions for the control of excavation of construction materials. 9. The functions of the Environmental Unit would include: (i) advising the SEOPC on environmental concerns in the transport sector; (ii) incorporating environmental objectives into feasibility and design studies; (iii) establishing environmental policies and procedures for road and other transport projects; (iv) ensuring compliance with the Environmental Manual for Road Design and Construction discussed below; (v) ensuring that all bidding documents and contracts contain the appropriate environmental conditions; and (vi) monitoring environmental factors and maintaining a database. 10. An Action Plan for strengthening DCCT was agreed during appraisal, which includes: (i) technical assistance to implement the proposed functions and procedures; (ii) special studies such as an ecological sensitivity map of DR for road infrastructure; (iii) purchase of equipment, including vehicles, computers, and geographical information systems; and (iv) training program for the DCCT and other relevant departments within the DCCT. This Action Plan will complement similar resources available under the IDB Rural Roads project.
 - 131 - D. Environmental Manual for Road Design and Construction 11. An Environmental Manual for Road Design and Construction has been prepared and will be adopted by SEOPC. The purpose of this manual is to establish specific rules for minimizng environmental damage during the construction and rehabilitation of roads. The manual defines specific penalties for each type of environmental violation by individual employees as well as by contracting companies. Examples of the topics that are included in the manual are: (i) applicable environmental and natural resource legislation that contractors have to comply with during construction and maintenance activities; (ii) explicit prohibitions and environmental behavior guidelines for work crews, specially along sensitive areas; (iii) proper selection and management of quarries, borrow pits, gravel extraction along rivers, and other sources of construction materials; (iv) eventual rehabilitation of affected areas through soil replacement and revegetation; (v) selection of camp sites, management of camp wastes and guidelines for camp dismantling and abandonment; (vi) proper disposal of excavated earth and spoil material to avoid contaminating streams or other unnecessary environmental damage; and (vii) proper disposal of wastes from construction machinery and equipment. 12. The EA report mentioned in para. 4 above also included the preparation of a Manual of Functions and Procedures for the Environmental Unit. These functions and procedures of the Environmental Unit as well as the Manual for Road Design and Construction will be officially adopted by SEOPC before project effectiveness.

Each project includes the widening followed by a maintenance strategy of routine maintenance, 100 percent patching, and resealings when the damaged area reaches 50%. The economic analysis compares the project with a base altemative that contains the same maintenance strategy adopted for the project case. Therefore, the economic analysis is measuring only the benefits due to the congestion reduction and due to the slower road deterioration of the widened roads caused by the spread of the trucks loading damage over a wider pavement surface. The widenings will more than double the road capacity and reduce the roadside friction caused by pedestrians, vendors, animals, etc. Thus, higher travel speeds are the mayor source of benefits. The costs of the maintenance operations were assumed to be the same as those considered for the reconstruction program (paragraph 13 of this Annex). The cost per kilometer of widening the three road varies from US$ 640,000 for the Santo Domingo-San Isidro highway to US$ 780,000 for the Santiago-Navarrete highway. 5. The economic analysis of the highway-widening component was undertaken with the application of the new version of the Highway Design and Maintenance Standards Model (1995 HDM System) which incorporates capacity constraints into the analysis of rehabilitation strategies. The HDM model performs a life-cycle analysis of the project and the base alternative, computing the yearly road deterioration and the resulting road agency and road user costs. The HDM model computes, for a given road and traffic, first the free-flow speeds and them adjust these speeds to take into account the congestion level. The resulting speeds are then used to compute the vehicle operating and travel time costs that are also a function of the road roughness, the road geometry, and vehicle characteristics. The diversion rate is estimated to vary between 35 and 50 percent, depending on the difference between the value of travel costs across the existing and the proposed roads.  - 143 - Highway Reconstruction and Resurfacing Programs 11. The economic analysis of reconstructing/rehabilitating 169 km and resurfacing 627.9 km of paved roads was carried out using the HDM model that is designed to recommend the solution which minimizes the net present value of the costs associated with each solution including vehicle operating costs and investment and maintenance costs. The higher the traffic level, the more rapid is the deterioration in road condition, and the more likely is a higher-cost investment alternative. 12. The sections to be rehabilitated or resurfaced were divided into homogeneous links in terms of traffic levels and physical condition. For each link, traffic was projected based on historical trends and expected population and production growth in the region. Using engineering data and climatic conditions, as well as traffic characteristics and cost parameters, the model simulated the operating conditions for each link and calculated total vehicle operating costs. The following options were examined for each road: (a) carrying out minimum maintenance at a cost of about US$ 360 per km; (b) carrying out minimum maintenance plus all required patching, at a cost, that varies according to the thickness of the road surface, of around US$ 9.00 per m2; (c) routine maintenance plus all patching plus sealing every 5 years at a cost of US$ 1.02 per m2; (d) overlays every 10 years at a cost estimated at around US$ 9.00 per m2, varying with the thickness of the road surface; and (e) reconstruction, at a cost of US$ 16.03 per m2 when road roughness reaches a predetermined level. The cost of rehabilitation and reconstruction was determined based on a preliminary engineering study for each road link. 13. An analysis performed to test the effects (risks) of postponing the widening and reconstruction investments shows that for all projects the net benefits are reduced if investments are postponed. Specifically, were investments postponed by one or two years, the Net Present Value for each project would decrease on average by 6 percent and 12 percent, respectively, though NPVs would remain greater than zero. This analysis shows that, from an economic perspective, the proposed sub-projects should be undertaken in earnest. Minor delays, however, would not affect the economic worthiness of the sub-projects. 15. An analysis performed to test the effects (risks) of not implementing an optimal maintenance policy after completion of the various rehabilitation and widening works, shows that benefits will decrease slightly if a proper maintenance program (including routine maintenance, patching and resealing) were not timely implemented. If only a limited routine maintenance is applied, the analysis shows that the NPV of sub-projects would decrease on average by 9 percent, though the economic rate of return remains greater than 12 percent for all sub-projects. The results reflect economic benefits for the
 - 146 - proposed sub-projects that are sustained even in light of sub-optimal maintenance policies. This is always the case for roads in good condition (as the ones being rehabilitated under the project) because vehicle operating costs vary in relation to road roughness progression and road roughness increases rapidly only once the road has deteriorated below a fair condition. Therefore, a sub-optimal maintenance policy affects economic benefits only marginally for roads in good condition. Conclusions 16. All sub-projects yield a rate of return of 12% and above including the events considered in the sensitivity analysis that increases the project costs or reduces the user benefits, except in the case of the reconstruction of the roads Boya - Sabana Grande, Don Juan-Dofia Maria, and Esperanza Mao, for which the EIRR falls to about 1 1.5%. We find this figure acceptable and, therefore, the sub-projects have been retained in the respective programs. The EIRR of the Bajos de Haina - Refineria widening and the Bani bridge are 8.6% and 8.0% in the case that the value of time is not included in the analysis, indicating that for these projects most of the benefits are derived from time savings. Due to the conservative value of time being adopted in the analysis and due to the fact that the purpose of these projects is to reduce congestion, we find the feasibility of these projects acceptable.  - 169- ANNEX 13 DOMINICAN REPUBLIC NATIONAL HIGHWAY PROJECT SUPERVISION PLAN STAFF INPUT FOR PROJECT LAUNCH AND ANNUAL AND MID-COURSE REVIEWS 1. The nature and scope of the project, the large programs of civil works and institutional strengthening, the use of new pavement technologies and the introduction to maintenance by contract and technical auditing will necessitate extensive and close supervision, especially during the first two years of project implementation. 2. A project launch mission and yearly project reviews will be organized, assisting the staff of the implementing agencies to develop a common understanding of the project's overall development objectives, operational procedures, coordination needs and potential implementation problems and to select the components to be implemented during the subsequent year. A qualified local expert will be engaged, for about two or three days a month, to follow up project implementation for the Bank. 3. The tentative composition and staffing level of the supervision plan and the supervision timetable are presented in Table A13. 1. All missions will involve discussions with the project officials in the SEOPC at its headquarters as well as field visits, on the basis of which the mission will evaluate the project. Following is a description of the purpose and objectives of each mission: 4. Project Launch Workshop. A project launch workshop will be conducted in the second quarter of 1997 to: (a) review and fine tune, as necessary, the implementation plan of the executing agency (SEOPC); (b) identify and plan the required coordination among the road directorates, and; (c) review project management, procurement, environmental assessment, disbursement, accounting and auditing procedures and requirements and technical assistance and training programs. 5. Annual Project Implementation Reviews. The purpose of the annual review is to: (a) assess the project performance against specific objectives and targets; (b) identify implementation problems and issues, and; (c) plan for the upcoming year, including the selection of subprojects.
 - 170 - 6. Mid-Term Implementation Review. This review will be carried out in December 1999 jointly by the Government and the Bank. The focus of the review is to ascertain to what extent the project has achieved its development objectives. The Project Coordinator will prepare the same reports for the Project Mid-Term Review as for the Annual Project Reviews. However, if special issues warrant more detailed analysis additional studies will be carried out. The mid-term review will cover the annual review coverage plus: (a) project performance; (b) identification of areas in need of adjustment; (c) status of execution of the institutional strengthening program; (d) implementation of the highway maintenance plan; (e) implementation of the Road Fund and the Road Agency (ONMV); (f) impact of technical assistance; (g) effectiveness of environmental assessment; and (h) availability of counterpart funds. 7. Modifications to Project Design. During the annual and mid-term reviews, there is an opportunity to update project targets and discuss changes needed in the project design or implementation plans. In this context, the Bank may require that the SEOPC prepare an action plan for the Bank's review and approval within two months following the completion of the corresponding project review. The SEOPC will incorporate the changes agreed upon in the project documents. The PCT Coordinator will be responsible for organizing the mid-term project review and ensuring that agreed follow-up actions, satisfactory to the Banks, are taken in a timely manner. 8. Implementation Plans. The project launch in FY97 will require 6 staff weeks. Annual reviews would require about 6 staff weeks per year. In addition, one regular supervision mission (one of one-week duration), comprising the task manager, a transport specialist and an institutional development specialist will be necessary. The mid-term review will require 9 staff weeks. Thus, total field supervision will amount to 55 staff weeks, and office supervision is expected to amount to an additional 25 weeks, for a total of 80 staff weeks during the life of the project, i.e. an average of about 16 staff weeks per year. 9. During the first two years of project implementation, supervision efforts will focus on organization and team development with a view toward strengthening the SEOPC's operational capacity. The project launch workshop will be followed by additional supervision input to familiarize selected local staff with the Bank's procurement, disbursement and auditing procedures and guidelines.
 - 171 - 10. Proposed Agenda for Annual and Mid-Term Implementation Reviews. The first annual project review will take place in February 1998. Annual reviews will focus on evaluation of progress against the implementation of the Transport Sector Policy and Strategy Statement and Action Plan and against agreed objective-oriented implementation, project performance indicators and technical audits, and will serve to update and revise the 1997-2000 Highway Program and to discuss issues of project management. The result of the annual review will be the agreement on the following year's program, and on remedial actions required to address problems or changing circumstances during implementation. 11. The mid-term review to be conducted not later than December 31, 1999 will follow the same format as the annual reviews but the analysis of project impact will be expanded. In addition to covering all the areas included in the annual reviews, the mid-term review will pay particular attention to reviewing compliance with the Transport Sector Policy and Strategy Statement and Action Plan, including: (a) Government's performance on project counterpart funding and on adequately funding road maintenance; (b) the environmental guidelines for SEOPC's activities; (c) achievement of stated performance goals; (d) effectiveness of technical assistance carried out under the project; and (e) experience with the environmental assessment of subprojects. 12. A summary of the areas to be addressed in the annual and mid-term reviews is presented below. 13. Sector Wide Lssues. Coordination of Sector Planning and Policies: Progress in the establishment of a functioning institutional framework for the coordination of sector investments and policy formulation; 14. Road Subsector Issues. (a) concentration of road subsector investments on rehabilitation and priority completion of projects; (b) availability and timeliness of project counterpart funds and road maintenance funds; (c) progress in continuing reduction of SEOPC staff; (d) effectiveness of technical assistance; (e) effectiveness and experience with the environmental assessment of subprojects; (f) technical ability, soundness of judgment and compliance with Bank guidelines in procurement and disbursements; and (g) private contractors' participation in road maintenance activities.

 - 173 - ANNEX 14 REPUBLICA DOMINICANA PROYECTO DE CARRETERAS NACIONALES TtRMINOS DE REFERENCLI PARA LA AUDITORiA FINANCIERO ADMINISTRATIVA Y DE CUMPLIMIENTO LEGAL 1. Selecci6n de la Firma. La firma sera seleccionada de acuerdo con el sistema de "lista breve" con un minimo de tres y un maximo de ocho firmas profesionales de auditoria de probada integridad, experiencia y reputaci6n. Esta selecci6n se efectuaria, para la auditoria contractual prevista por el proyecto, a partir del 31 de Diciembre del 1997. 2. Normas de Trabajo. El trabajo se efectuara de acuerdo con la normas recomendadas por el "Comite de Auditoria" de la Federaci6n Intemacional de Contadores, las recomendadas por el Instituto de Contadores P(iblicos Autorizados de la Repuiblica Dominicana y las pautadas por el Banco Mundial en su documentaci6n FARAH y FM-600 (Pautas Minimas Sugeridas para la Auditoria de Prestatarios, Entidades Ejecutoras o Intermediarias y Operaciones Financiadas por el Banco Mundial). En el alcance del trabajo que se muestra mas adelante se presenta un resumen de los principales componentes de la auditoria e informaci6n financiera requeridos por el Banco Mundial. 3. Periodicidad de los Informes. Se requerira un informe anual de auditoria financiero-administrativa y de cumplimiento sobre las oficinas ejecutoras y los proyectos financiados por el Banco Mundial. El Banco podra requerir que dicho informe se emita por periodos mas breves (por ejemplo, semestrales), en cuyo caso el ultimo informe, al 31 de Diciembre de cada ejercicio econ6mico, debera incluir el resumen de la ejecuci6n financiero-operativa del proyecto durante todo el anio. 4. Simultaneidad de Informes. Se recomienda que la firma de auditores a cargo del examen se mantenga en contacto y, si fuese necesario, planifique su trabajo con la firma de ingenieros auditores que haya sido aprobada para la realizaci6n de la ejecuci6n anual de caracter fisico-operativo y de cumplimiento legal tecnico que hubiese sido aprobada. La firma de auditoria financiera debera a su vez establecer contacto y efectuar su trabajo en concordancia con la firma de auditores-ingenieros, sobre todo en aquellos sectores del trabajo en que por su naturaleza resulte conveniente que se realicen de manera conjunta, aun cuando cada firma se responsabilice por el trabajo efectuado por ella misma. 5. Elaboracion del Contrato de Servicios Profesionales. Antes del comienzo de la auditoria se elaborara un "convenio de servicios profesionales" entre la SEOPC y la firma auditora. Este convenio se preparara de acuerdo con las practicas comunes para este tipo de servicios y debera incluir la provisi6n de que: (i) el Banco Mundial podra tener acceso directo a la firma auditora incluyendo los papeles de trabajo de la auditoria practicada; (ii) los diversos informes de auditoria requeridos por el Banco Mundial seran entregados a la SEOPC en una fecha que permita a esta la rernisi6n de tales informes al Banco Mundial para la fecha limite prevista en los respectivos convenios de prestamo (y que en caso de
 - 174 - que el auditor documentase la imposibilidad de cumplir con este requisito, 6l remitiria una carta a la SEOPC con copia para el Banco Mundial, indicando las razones que impedirian dicho cumplimiento y la solicitud del prestatario al Banco Mundial solicitando al Banco autorizaci6n para la nueva fecha de entrega). 6. El contrato de servicios no debera incluir clausula punitiva alguna por demora en la entrega del informe si previamente se di6 cumplimiento al procedimiento descrito. El convenio de servicios se referira a los terminos de referencia, los cuales constituiran parte integrante del contrato de servicio en cuesti6n. 7. Documentaci6n Basica para la Realizaci6n de la Auditoria. Se supone que la firma auditora antes de comenzar el trabajo habra tomado en consideraci6n o leido: (i) las nomnas de la FIC; (ii) las recomendaciones del Comite Intemacional de Normas Contables; (iii) el Documento de Evaluaci6n del Proyecto (Staff Appraisal Report-SAR), preparado por el Banco Mundial (iv) el Convenio de Prestamo del Banco Mundial correspondiente al Proyecto sujeto a examen; (v) las Ayudas-Memoria preparadas por las misiones de Supervisi6n del Banco Mundial sobre las anteriores funciones y la correspondencia entre la SEOPC y el Banco Mundial referente a la ejecuci6n fisico- financiera del proyecto, los desembolsos a cuenta del prestamo incluyendo los referentes a los Certificados de Gastos-SOE, y otra documentaci6n relevante con referencia al Proyecto; (vi) la legislaci6n y reglamentaci6n del pais referente a obras puiblicas, incluyendo la de protecci6n del medio ambiente; y (vii) otra documentaci6n relevante a la ejecuci6n de la auditoria. 8. Informes de Auditoria Requeridos. (a) opini6n sobre el Estado de Origen y Aplicaci6n de Recursos Invertidos en el Proyecto y la "informaci6n financiera suplementaria" correspondiente (una sola opini6n para ambos); comparaci6n fisico financiera de la ejecuci6n; incorporaci6n, en la infommaci6n financiera sobre el proyecto, de los eventuales activos, pasivos, contingencias, costos y gastos de caracter ambiental; flujo de desembolsos (aportes locales convenidos y fondos del Prestamo del Banco Mundial); cumplimiento con los indices de gesti6n y eficiencia; analisis de las licitaciones, contratos y contratistas; analisis de la utilizaci6n de la Asistencia Tecnica en consultores, estudios, etc.; (b) opini6n sobre la razonabilidad y elegibilidad de los Certificados de Gastos- SOEs, emitidos durante el periodo y los controles ejercidos en el manejo de los mismos; (c) opini6n sobre el Estado de Transacciones y Disponibilidad de fondos mantenidos en la Cuenta Especial (incluyendo comentarios sobre el registro y control ejercido por el banco depositario);
 - 175 - (d) opini6n sobre la calidad aparente de la Estructura de los Controles Internos contable-financiero-administrativos ejercidos por la administracion del Proyecto sobre la gesti6n financiera del mismo; (e) opini6n (no "aseveraci6n negativa") sobre el cumplimiento legal: (i) con las leyes y reglamentos nacionales que pudieran afectar la ejecuci6n financiero operativa y ambiental de la SEOPC y del Proyecto; y (ii) con las clausulas y anexos del Convenio de Prestamo, incluyendo las referentes a la ejecuci6n del Proyecto, las de caricter financiero, la utilizaci6n de los recursos del Prestamo, la de Adquisiciones y Consultores y la de la Cuenta Especial. (f) "Carta a la Direcci6n" o de Asesoria Gerencial incluyendo: (i) comentarios y ajustes a las cuentas examinadas; (ii) comentarios sobre cualquier deficiencia seria observada sobre los controles internos (referencia cruzada al informe en d); (iii) comentarios sobre la adecuaci6n del sistema de registro e informaci6n contable-financiera, incluyendo el reconocimiento en las cuentas del proyecto del eventual impacto ambiental (activos, pasivos, costos, contingencias, etc.) derivado de la observaci6n de las leyes y reglamentos de protecci6n del medio ambiente; (iv) comentarios sobre el "examen de vulnerabilidad" efectuado, incluyendo, si fuese el caso, cualquier comentario sobre situaciones serias que implicarian situaciones de fraude, despilfarro, abusos administrativos, actos ilicitos y otras irregularidades que atentarian al mantenimiento de un ambiente de integridad y 6tica y de responsabilidad financiera respecto a la administraci6n del Proyecto; (v) comentarios, emergentes del examen practicado, tendentes a mejorar la economia y la eficiencia en la gesti6n del Proyecto y a evaluar los resultados alcanzados frente a las expectativas originales (tiempo y costo) del Gobiemo Nacional y el Banco Mundial (auditoria de eficacia); y (vi) medidas adoptadas por la administraci6n de Proyecto respecto a las sugerencias y recomendaciones de los auditores referentes a auditorias anteriores y aceptadas en esa oportunidad por la administraci6n.

doc.abstracts: The National Highway Project has two broad objectives: a) to improve transport sector's contribution to the development of major sources of growth and improve access to markets; and b) to consolidate the gains in the institutional capacity of the Secretariat of State of Public Works and Communication (SEOPC) under Loan 3350-DO to maintain the road network in a stable condition without continued donor support and enforce new practices and policies started under that loan. The project consists of four components: a) civil works program - consisting of highway construction resurfacing and maintenance, bridge construction, and a road signalization program; b) supervision and technical auditing component; c) acquisition of goods including vehicles, spare parts and office equipment; and d) consulting services and training.
